lens.book_chapters: Chapter 8: How to Appraise Your Organization's Capabilities and Disabilities (RPV Framework); Chapter 9: Performance Provided, Market Demand, and the Product Life Cycle (Performance Oversupply)
lens.lens_summary: Facebook Marketplace's Resources, Processes, and Values are optimized for general-purpose commerce at scale, making it structurally incapable of building the trust architecture that shared housing demands — and its 'good enough' housing listings represent classic performance oversupply on discoverability while catastrophically undersupplying on the trust, commitment, and lifecycle management dimensions where the basis of competition is shifting.

competitor_overview.primary_strength: Massive distribution and zero-friction discovery — billions of users already inside the app, no separate download or signup required. Social graph proximity surfaces listings from friends-of-friends. Do NOT compete here.
competitor_overview.business_model: Advertising revenue and ecosystem engagement. Marketplace exists to increase time-on-platform and ad inventory, not to monetize housing transactions directly. This means Facebook has no financial incentive to build housing-specific trust infrastructure — it would add cost without adding ad revenue.
competitor_overview.user_base: Casual browsers who already spend time on Facebook. Skews toward people who stumble upon listings organically rather than conducting deliberate housing searches. Also attracts budget-conscious renters and hosts who want to avoid platform fees. Wide demographic but over-indexes on users comfortable with informal, peer-to-peer transactions.
competitor_overview.brand_perception: Convenient but untrustworthy for high-stakes transactions. Users associate Marketplace with selling furniture and finding deals, not with making life decisions. There is a pervasive 'scam anxiety' — users know that Marketplace is full of fraudulent listings, ghost profiles, and no-show contacts, but tolerate it because the price is right (free) and the reach is unmatched.

discovery.what_they_do: Listings appear in a dedicated Marketplace tab, in Facebook Feed via algorithmic surfacing, and through Facebook Groups (housing-specific groups like 'Rooms for Rent in [City]'). Users can also share listing links in Messenger. Discovery is passive and social-graph-powered — you see what's near you and what friends have interacted with. There is no dedicated shared-housing discovery flow; housing listings sit alongside furniture, cars, and electronics.
discovery.framework_analysis: Chapter 8's Resources framework explains exactly why discovery is excellent: Facebook's resources — 3+ billion users, the social graph, algorithmic feed placement, location data, and Messenger integration — are unmatched and essentially unreplicable. These are resources in the purest Christensen sense: things that can be bought, hired, and deployed. No startup can acquire this resource base. However, Chapter 8 also warns that resources alone don't determine capability — processes and values must align too. Facebook's discovery resources are deployed through processes designed for general commerce (showing items algorithmically based on engagement signals, not housing-fit signals) and values that prioritize engagement metrics over match quality.
discovery.what_nobody_in_category_does: Nobody in the shared-housing category provides context-aware discovery that accounts for lifestyle compatibility, schedule alignment, or cohabitation fit. Marketplace discovers listings; it does not discover compatibility. The entire category treats housing discovery as a search problem ('find a room near work under $X') when shared housing is fundamentally a matching problem ('find a person whose life patterns are compatible with mine'). This is the mediocre coffee — discovery is universally treated as a logistics question, never a trust question.

evidence.observation: Christensen defines resources as 'people, equipment, technology, product designs, brands, information, cash, and relationships with suppliers, distributors, and customers' — things that can be transferred across organizations. Facebook's social graph, user base, and algorithmic feed are textbook resources that create enormous discovery capability.
evidence.framework_interpretation: The RPV framework predicts that Facebook will always win on resource-dependent capabilities like reach and distribution. Competing on discovery volume is competing on resources — the one dimension where incumbents have permanent advantages. The opportunity lies in processes and values, which Facebook cannot transfer from its general commerce operation to a housing-specific context.

evidence.observation: Housing listings appear in the same feed as used iPhones, baby strollers, and pickup trucks. There is no distinct entry point for 'I'm looking for a shared living situation' versus 'I'm looking for a studio apartment' versus 'I'm looking for a sublet.' The category filter is 'Property Rentals' — a flat taxonomy that collapses all housing needs into one bucket.
evidence.framework_interpretation: This is a direct manifestation of what Chapter 8 calls organizational values shaping prioritization. Facebook's values prioritize breadth of marketplace categories and engagement across all of them. Building a dedicated shared-housing discovery flow would be de-prioritized because it serves a small fraction of total Marketplace GMV. The values of the organization make it structurally unable to invest disproportionately in one niche.

search.what_they_do: Users can filter by location (radius from a point), price range, number of bedrooms, and property type. Search is keyword-based within the Marketplace search bar. Results are sorted by recency and relevance (engagement signals). There are no filters for lease style, schedule, lifestyle preferences, house rules, or cohabitation dynamics. Photos are user-uploaded with no quality standards.
search.framework_analysis: Chapter 9's buying hierarchy (functionality -> reliability -> convenience -> price) illuminates why search is merely adequate. Facebook Marketplace has satisfied the basic functionality requirement of search: you can find listings in your area within your budget. But the basis of competition in shared housing is shifting beyond functionality (can I find a listing?) toward reliability (can I trust this listing is real and accurate?) and convenience (can I quickly determine if this is a fit for my life?). Marketplace's search oversupplies on volume of results while undersupplying on reliability and convenience — the exact pattern Christensen describes as creating disruptive opportunity.
search.what_nobody_in_category_does: Nobody provides search that filters on cohabitation compatibility dimensions: schedule overlap, cleanliness standards, noise tolerance, guest policies, work-from-home patterns, or personality type. Search across the entire category remains a real-estate search paradigm (location, price, bedrooms) applied to what is fundamentally a relationship-matching problem. The search filters that would actually matter most to someone choosing a person to share a home with simply do not exist anywhere.

evidence.source: Chapter 9 — Performance Oversupply and Changing Bases of Competition
evidence.observation: Christensen describes how once two or more products satisfy market demand for functionality, 'customers can no longer base their choice of products on functionality, but tend to choose a product and vendor based on reliability.' In shared housing search, the functionality of 'find a listing near me' has been oversupplied. The basis of competition is shifting to reliability ('Is this listing real? Is this person safe?') and convenience ('Can I quickly assess fit without messaging 20 people?').
evidence.framework_interpretation: Marketplace is winning on the old basis of competition (volume of discoverable listings) while ignoring the emerging basis of competition (trustworthiness and fit-assessment efficiency). This is the classic innovator's dilemma pattern — the incumbent oversupplies on yesterday's performance dimension while a disruptor can win by satisfying the new dimension, even with fewer listings.

evidence.observation: The available search filters for housing are: location, price, bedrooms, bathrooms, property type, square footage, laundry, parking, AC, heating, and pet policy. These are all physical-space attributes. There are zero filters related to the person you'd be living with, the schedule of the arrangement, or the social dynamics of the household.
evidence.framework_interpretation: Chapter 8's Values framework explains this: Facebook's organizational values are built around general commerce, where physical attributes of goods are the relevant search dimensions. The values that would prioritize building person-matching search infrastructure don't exist within Facebook's decision-making hierarchy — such a feature would be deprioritized because it serves too narrow a use case relative to the effort required.

listing_evaluation.what_they_do: A listing detail page shows photos (variable quality, no verification), a text description written by the poster, price, location (approximate), and basic property attributes. The poster's Facebook profile is linked — users can click through to see the person's public profile, mutual friends, and how long they've been on Facebook. There is no structured verification, no reviews of the host as a housing provider, no verified identity beyond whatever Facebook's general account verification provides, and no standardized information architecture.
listing_evaluation.framework_analysis: This is where performance oversupply analysis becomes most revealing. Chapter 9 explains that when a technology oversupplies on one dimension, the basis of competition shifts to the next dimension in the buying hierarchy. Facebook has oversupplied on listing volume and ease of posting (functionality) but dramatically undersupplied on listing reliability (the next stage). A guest evaluating a shared-housing listing needs to answer: Is this listing real? Is this person safe to live with? Is this description accurate? Will this person honor their commitments? Facebook's listing evaluation provides zero structured mechanisms to answer any of these questions. The social profile serves as a crude proxy for trust, but it was built for social networking, not housing trust assessment.
listing_evaluation.what_nobody_in_category_does: Nobody provides structured trust signals specific to shared housing: verified occupancy history, past cohabitant reviews, identity verification tied to housing context, cleanliness documentation, noise-level evidence, or behavioral consistency metrics. The entire category relies on either raw social profiles (Marketplace) or generic star ratings (Airbnb, which is short-stay). Nobody has built a trust architecture designed specifically for the 'Will I be safe and comfortable sharing a home with this specific person for weeks or months?' question.

evidence.source: Chapter 9 — The Buying Hierarchy (Windermere Associates model)
evidence.observation: The buying hierarchy progresses: functionality -> reliability -> convenience -> price. Once functionality is satisfied ('I can find listings'), customers shift to reliability ('I can trust these listings'). Christensen notes that 'performance oversupply triggers a shift in the basis of competition, and the criteria used by customers to choose one product over another changes to attributes for which market demands are not yet satisfied.'
evidence.framework_interpretation: Facebook Marketplace has pushed listing functionality well past the point of oversupply — anyone can post a listing in seconds. But this ease of posting is precisely what undermines reliability: because anyone can post anything, there's no quality floor. The very process that makes Marketplace excellent at listing volume makes it structurally weak at listing trustworthiness. This is a textbook case of Christensen's point that capabilities simultaneously create disabilities.

evidence.source: Facebook Marketplace UX — Listing detail page
evidence.observation: A typical shared-housing listing on Marketplace shows 3-8 photos of variable quality, a freeform text description that ranges from one sentence to a wall of text, a price, and a link to the poster's personal Facebook profile. There is no verification badge, no review score, no response-rate indicator, no identity verification, and no structured fields for house rules, schedule expectations, or lifestyle preferences.
evidence.framework_interpretation: Chapter 8's Processes framework explains why: Facebook's listing creation process is designed for general commerce — post photos, write a description, set a price. This process was refined for selling couches and cars, where the physical object is the entire transaction. For shared housing, the 'object' is a relationship with a person, not a physical space — but Facebook's processes have no mechanism to capture or communicate that. And per Chapter 8, processes are 'intrinsically inimical to change.'

evidence.observation: Searches for 'Facebook Marketplace rental scam' return thousands of results. Common complaints include fake listings using stolen photos, people who collect deposits and disappear, listings that don't match the actual space, and accounts impersonating real landlords. The scam problem is widely known but unresolved.
evidence.framework_interpretation: This is what Chapter 9 predicts when performance oversupply on one dimension (volume/access) goes unaddressed while the next dimension (reliability/trust) is undersupplied. The gap between what users need on trust and what the platform provides is the exact space where a disruptive entrant can establish a beachhead.

booking_proposal.what_they_do: There is no booking or proposal mechanism. Users click 'Message' on a listing to open a Messenger conversation with the poster. All negotiation happens through unstructured chat — price, dates, move-in timing, house rules, deposit terms, and everything else is discussed ad hoc. There is no structured proposal, no counter-offer flow, no price calculator, and no terms template. The 'transaction' is entirely informal and happens off-platform (cash, Venmo, Zelle) or not at all.
booking_proposal.framework_analysis: Chapter 8's RPV framework explains this absence with precision. Facebook's Processes for commerce transactions are: browse -> message -> arrange meetup -> exchange in person (or ship via Commerce policies for goods). This process was designed for one-time goods transactions. Housing requires a fundamentally different process: proposal -> negotiation -> counter-offer -> agreement -> contract -> payment schedule -> ongoing management. Facebook's existing processes cannot accommodate this without being rebuilt from scratch. Furthermore, Facebook's Values deprioritize building this: the revenue per housing transaction is zero (no fees), while the engineering cost of building a structured negotiation system would be enormous. Per Chapter 8, 'the very mechanisms through which organizations create value are intrinsically inimical to change.'
booking_proposal.what_nobody_in_category_does: Nobody in the general marketplace category provides a structured negotiation flow for shared housing that handles the unique multi-dimensional nature of the agreement: not just price, but which nights, which spaces, which rules, for how long, with what cancellation terms, and with what flexibility for changes. Even Airbnb's booking flow is a take-it-or-leave-it model (host sets fixed terms, guest accepts or doesn't). A true proposal-counter-proposal negotiation system for shared housing terms does not exist in any major platform.

evidence.observation: Christensen writes: 'Some of the most crucial processes to examine as capabilities or disabilities aren't the obvious value-adding processes involved in logistics, development, manufacturing, and customer service. Rather, they are the enabling or background processes that support investment decision-making.' Facebook's background processes — how it decides what to build — are optimized for features that increase engagement across billions of users. A structured housing-proposal system serves maybe 0.1% of Marketplace users.
evidence.framework_interpretation: The decision-making processes within Facebook will consistently deprioritize building a housing negotiation system because the ROI calculation, run through Facebook's existing processes and values, will never justify the investment. This isn't a failure of imagination — it's a structural inability baked into the organization's RPV configuration. This is exactly the 'disability' side of the capabilities-create-disabilities coin that Chapter 8 describes.

evidence.observation: Clicking 'Is this still available?' on a housing listing opens a generic Messenger thread. The auto-suggested message is identical to what appears for a used bicycle listing. There is no housing-specific template, no structured fields for proposed dates or terms, and no way to formalize an offer within the platform.
evidence.framework_interpretation: This is a perfect illustration of Christensen's point that processes refined for one purpose cannot simultaneously serve a fundamentally different purpose. Messenger's conversational process works well for simple commerce ('Is this still available? Can I pick it up Tuesday?') but is structurally incapable of supporting multi-term housing negotiation without complete redesign.

communication.what_they_do: All communication happens through Facebook Messenger. Messenger is a general-purpose chat platform with text, photos, voice messages, video calls, reactions, and group chat capabilities. There are no housing-specific communication features: no arrival notifications, no cleaning verification, no house-manual delivery, no payment reminders, and no structured status updates. Communication is entirely ad hoc and unstructured.
communication.framework_analysis: This is a subtle case of performance oversupply described in Chapter 9. Messenger oversupplies on raw communication capability — it can handle text, voice, video, file sharing, and group conversations, far exceeding what most housing platforms offer. But this raw capability oversupplies on the wrong dimension. For shared housing, the need is not 'can I send a message?' (functionality oversupplied) but 'does the communication system help me manage the ongoing logistics of cohabitation?' (reliability and convenience undersupplied). Christensen's buying hierarchy predicts that once basic messaging functionality is satisfied, users shift to valuing structured, reliable communication workflows — and Messenger provides none.
communication.what_nobody_in_category_does: Nobody provides communication workflows specifically designed for the ongoing rhythm of shared housing: automated arrival/departure notifications, post-stay cleaning verification with photo documentation, house-manual access integrated into the communication flow, payment-linked status updates, or date-change request workflows embedded in the messaging context. Communication in every platform is either generic chat (Marketplace, Craigslist) or rigid booking-status updates (Airbnb). Nobody has designed communication for the unique cadence of a recurring shared-housing relationship.

evidence.observation: Christensen's buying hierarchy (functionality -> reliability -> convenience -> price) describes how once two or more products satisfy basic functionality needs, competition shifts to reliability, then convenience. Messenger satisfies communication functionality but provides no reliability scaffolding (no structured workflows, no audit trails specific to housing, no accountability mechanisms) and no convenience features for housing management.
evidence.framework_interpretation: The performance oversupply on raw messaging capability masks the undersupply on housing-specific communication structure. Users 'make do' with Messenger because it works for sending messages, but the absence of structured workflows means critical moments (arrival notifications, cleaning verification, dispute documentation) rely entirely on individual initiative and informal norms. This is the 'adequate coffee' — it works, nobody complains about it specifically, but nobody has imagined what great communication for shared housing could look like.

evidence.source: Facebook Messenger UX in housing context
evidence.observation: Messenger threads between housing participants look identical to any other Messenger conversation. There are no pinned agreements, no embedded house rules, no payment status indicators, no stay calendars, and no structured check-in/check-out prompts. Important logistics details get buried in scroll-back, and there is no way to distinguish 'social chat' from 'housing logistics' within the same thread.
evidence.framework_interpretation: Chapter 8's Processes framework: Messenger's processes were built for social communication. The interaction patterns, notification logic, and information architecture are optimized for casual conversation, not for managing a contractual living arrangement. These processes would need fundamental redesign to serve housing communication — and per Christensen, 'processes are very hard to change.'

active_stay.what_they_do: Facebook Marketplace provides zero active-stay management. Once a housing arrangement is made (informally, through Messenger), Facebook's involvement effectively ends. There is no stay tracking, no payment processing, no date management, no calendar integration, no house-manual delivery, and no dispute resolution. The active stay exists entirely outside the platform.
active_stay.framework_analysis: Chapter 8's Values framework is the definitive explanation for this absence. Christensen writes that values are 'the standards by which employees make prioritization decisions — by which they judge whether an order is attractive or unattractive; whether a customer is more important or less important; whether an idea for a new product is attractive or marginal.' Facebook's values are calibrated to engagement metrics and advertising revenue at massive scale. Active-stay management for a tiny fraction of housing users is, by Facebook's values, marginal. It will never clear the prioritization bar. Furthermore, as Chapter 8 explains, companies that have grown large need large revenue opportunities: 'In order for a $40 billion company to grow 25 percent, it needs to find $10 billion in new business the next year.' Housing stay management is a rounding error.
active_stay.what_nobody_in_category_does: Nobody in the general marketplace category provides any form of active-stay management. Even Airbnb's active-stay features are minimal (a reservation card with check-in instructions). Nobody provides real-time stay management tools: flexible date modification during an active arrangement, cleaning verification workflows, mid-stay issue escalation, or payment adjustment based on actual usage. The entire post-booking lifecycle is a dead zone across every platform in the category.

evidence.observation: Christensen explains that as companies grow, their values shift to require larger opportunities: 'Because a company's stock price represents the discounted present value of its projected earnings stream, most managers typically feel compelled not just to maintain growth, but to maintain a constant rate of growth.' Facebook/Meta generates approximately $135B in annual revenue. Building housing stay management tools would be an infinitesimal contribution to growth, making it impossible to prioritize within Facebook's value system.
evidence.framework_interpretation: This is the exact mechanism by which large companies systematically ignore small-market opportunities that later become large markets. Facebook cannot build active-stay management not because it lacks the engineering resources, but because its values — its prioritization criteria — will never surface this as a worthy investment. This is the disability that Chapter 8 says is inseparable from the capability: the same values that let Facebook execute at global scale prevent it from investing in niche-but-critical features.

evidence.source: Industry pattern — marketplace platforms and post-transaction lifecycle
evidence.observation: General marketplace platforms (Facebook Marketplace, Craigslist, OfferUp, Nextdoor) universally treat transactions as discrete events that end at the point of sale or handoff. None provide lifecycle management for ongoing arrangements. This is a structural pattern: marketplace business models are optimized for transaction volume, not transaction depth.
evidence.framework_interpretation: Chapter 8's observation that 'the very mechanisms through which organizations create value are intrinsically inimical to change' applies to the entire marketplace category. The processes that make marketplaces successful — low-friction listing, broad discovery, quick transactions — are precisely the processes that prevent them from building deep, ongoing relationship management. This is a category-level disability, not just a Facebook-specific one.

post_stay.what_they_do: There is no post-stay phase. Facebook has no concept of a 'stay' in its Marketplace product, so there is nothing to follow up on. There are no housing-specific reviews, no experience ratings, no cleaning assessments, and no feedback loops. Users may or may not leave a general Facebook recommendation on the person's profile, but this is a social-network feature, not a housing-transaction feature.
post_stay.framework_analysis: Chapter 9's performance oversupply model reveals why this absence is so significant. Christensen's buying hierarchy shows that once functionality and reliability are satisfied, competition shifts to convenience, then price. But what happens when a platform never satisfies reliability in the first place? The answer: the market stagnates at the functionality stage, and users compensate with informal workarounds (asking mutual friends, doing social-media research on potential housemates, requesting references via DM). Post-stay reviews are the primary mechanism by which housing platforms could build reliability. Their absence on Marketplace means the platform is permanently stuck at the functionality stage of the buying hierarchy, unable to progress. This is exactly the opening a disruptive entrant needs.
post_stay.what_nobody_in_category_does: Nobody provides reciprocal, housing-specific reviews that accumulate over individual stays within a longer arrangement. Airbnb has reviews, but they are per-booking and oriented toward short-term hospitality, not cohabitation dynamics. Nobody captures the specific dimensions that matter for shared housing trust: adherence to house rules, cleanliness consistency, noise respect, communication responsiveness during a stay, and accuracy of listing description versus lived reality. The review systems that exist across the category are borrowed from hospitality or general commerce — none are native to shared housing.

evidence.source: Chapter 9 — The weakness of disruptive technologies is their strength
evidence.observation: Christensen writes: 'It is often the very attributes that render disruptive technologies useless in mainstream markets that constitute their value in new markets.' A platform that requires structured reviews, verified identities, and detailed house manuals would be slower and more effortful than Marketplace's instant-post model. These 'weaknesses' (friction, structure, process) are actually strengths in the shared-housing context because they build the trust infrastructure that casual marketplaces cannot.
evidence.framework_interpretation: What would look like a disability in the general-marketplace context — requiring reviews, enforcing structured listings, mandating identity verification — becomes a capability in the shared-housing context. This is the classic disruptive technology pattern: the attributes that make it uncompetitive in the mainstream market (slower, more structured, more friction) are exactly what the underserved market needs.

evidence.observation: After a Marketplace transaction, the only prompt is a generic 'Rate this transaction' with a thumbs up/thumbs down and optional comment. This rating system was designed for one-time goods purchases. There is no mechanism to rate a housing experience, rate a person as a housemate, or build a housing-specific reputation over time.
evidence.framework_interpretation: Facebook's general-purpose rating process cannot be adapted to housing without fundamental redesign. Per Chapter 8, this is a process disability: the existing feedback processes were built for simple commerce and 'are intrinsically inimical to change.' Building a housing-specific review system would require new processes that contradict the speed and simplicity values of the existing Marketplace operation.

retention.what_they_do: Facebook retains users through general platform stickiness — people return to Facebook for social networking, not for housing management. There is no housing-specific retention mechanism: no rebooking prompts, no loyalty benefits, no relationship continuity features, and no way to maintain an ongoing host-guest relationship through the platform. If a housing arrangement ends and the parties want to arrange another one, they start from scratch on Marketplace or continue communicating through Messenger informally.
retention.framework_analysis: Chapter 8's Values framework reveals the deepest reason for weak retention in housing: Facebook's values measure success in daily active users and advertising engagement, not in housing-arrangement renewals or host-guest relationship longevity. The organization literally does not have metrics, processes, or incentive structures that would cause anyone to notice or care about housing retention. Furthermore, Christensen's observation about growth requirements means that even if someone at Facebook identified housing retention as an opportunity, the potential revenue would be too small to attract organizational attention and resources.
retention.what_nobody_in_category_does: Nobody builds retention around the host-guest relationship as an asset that appreciates over time. In shared housing, a proven host-guest pairing is enormously valuable — both parties have established trust, norms, and expectations. Yet no platform treats this relationship as a first-class object that can be maintained, extended, or renewed. Every platform treats each booking or arrangement as independent, discarding the accumulated trust and behavioral knowledge from previous interactions. This is the deepest blind spot in the entire category: the relationship is the product, but nobody manages the relationship lifecycle.

evidence.observation: Christensen's central thesis in Chapter 8: 'The very capabilities of their organizations also define their disabilities.' Facebook's capability of retaining users through broad social-network engagement simultaneously creates a disability in retaining users for any specific vertical use case. The platform's strength (everyone is already there for social reasons) means there's no felt need to build housing-specific retention. Why build a rebooking flow when the user will come back to Facebook anyway?
evidence.framework_interpretation: This is a subtle but critical insight. Facebook's general retention capability masks the absence of housing-specific retention. Because users return to the platform daily for social reasons, Facebook never observes the 'churn' in its housing use case — the data signal that would normally trigger a retention initiative is invisible. A dedicated housing platform would see the churn clearly and be motivated to solve it. This is an example of how large organizations' values and measurement processes structurally prevent them from even seeing small-market problems.

evidence.observation: General marketplaces retain users through breadth of selection and habitual browsing, not through relationship continuity. This model works well for goods (you need new things regularly) but poorly for housing (you need stable, recurring arrangements). No marketplace platform has adapted its retention model for ongoing relationship-based use cases.
evidence.framework_interpretation: Chapter 9's performance oversupply model applies here: marketplaces have oversupplied on 'new listing discovery' (the retention mechanism for goods commerce) while undersupplying on 'relationship continuity' (the retention mechanism needed for shared housing). The basis of competition for housing retention is not 'do you have new listings?' but 'can you help me maintain and deepen the arrangements that already work?'

split_lease_phase_mapping.discovery: Phase 1 (Host Creates a Listing — Homepage and listing creation) + Phase 2 (Guest arrives at listing — Homepage and Listing Detail Page)
split_lease_phase_mapping.search: Phase 2 (Guest navigates to the Host's listing — Listing Detail Page with duration selector and day-of-week selection)
split_lease_phase_mapping.listing_evaluation: Phase 2 (Guest reviews the Listing Detail Page — nightly rate, 4-week rent, space details, photos, rules, and features)
split_lease_phase_mapping.booking_proposal: Phase 2 (Guest clicks 'Create Proposal' and submits) + Phase 3 (Host reviews and counters via Edit Proposal Terms) + Phase 4 (Guest accepts Host's counter-terms)
split_lease_phase_mapping.communication: Phase 5 (Host-Guest Communication — arrival notifications, cleaning photos, general messaging via platform)
split_lease_phase_mapping.active_stay: Phase 5 (Leases page, Stays Manager, Date Change Tool — add/remove/swap dates, payment schedule management)
split_lease_phase_mapping.post_stay: Phase 5 (Stay Review — Guest reviews Host and space; Host reviews Guest — after each individual stay)
split_lease_phase_mapping.retention: Phase 5 (Leases page as central hub for active and completed leases — ongoing relationship management and potential rebooking)

category_blind_spots.blind_spot: Trust architecture native to shared housing — no platform has built a trust system designed for 'will I be safe and comfortable sharing a home with this specific person for an extended period?' as opposed to 'is this product/listing legitimate?'
category_blind_spots.why_nobody_tries: General marketplaces are structured around transaction-level trust (did the seller deliver?), not relationship-level trust (will this person be a good cohabitant?). Building relationship trust requires entirely different processes — ongoing review cycles, behavioral consistency tracking, identity verification beyond account creation — that don't exist in any marketplace's current process library. Per Chapter 8, these new processes would need to be built from scratch, which marketplace organizations are structurally unable to prioritize.
category_blind_spots.framework_insight: Chapter 8 explains that processes are 'intrinsically inimical to change' and that organizations' capabilities simultaneously create their disabilities. Every marketplace's trust processes were designed for discrete transactions. These processes cannot be incrementally adapted to serve ongoing cohabitation trust — they would need to be fundamentally rebuilt. Chapter 9 adds that trust in shared housing is where the basis of competition is shifting: functionality (can I find a listing?) is oversupplied, and reliability (can I trust this person?) is the new battleground. The first platform to satisfy the reliability demand will capture the market, just as Intuit's Quickbooks captured 70% of the small-business accounting market by addressing the convenience dimension that incumbents had oversupplied past.

category_blind_spots.blind_spot: The negotiation-as-product gap — no platform treats the housing agreement negotiation itself as a designed product experience. Everywhere, negotiation is either absent (Marketplace — just message the person), rigid (Airbnb — accept the host's fixed terms), or primitive (Craigslist — email back and forth). Nobody has designed a structured, multi-dimensional negotiation flow where both parties propose, counter, and converge on terms across price, schedule, duration, rules, and flexibility.
category_blind_spots.why_nobody_tries: Marketplace platforms are built on the assumption that transactions are simple: a good has a price, the buyer accepts or doesn't. Housing negotiation is multi-dimensional and iterative — it doesn't fit the 'list price -> buy' process that every marketplace uses. Building a negotiation flow requires designing for a fundamentally different transaction type, which means building fundamentally different processes. Per Chapter 8, existing marketplace processes cannot accommodate this without organizational restructuring.
category_blind_spots.framework_insight: Chapter 8's Values framework explains why no marketplace builds negotiation: negotiation adds friction, complexity, and development cost to a process that marketplaces have spent years simplifying. Marketplace values prioritize transaction speed and volume — negotiation is antithetical to these values. But Chapter 9's buying hierarchy reveals that for shared housing, negotiation IS the product. The ability to negotiate terms (not just accept them) is the reliability and convenience dimension that the market demands. This is where a disruptive entrant can establish an 'inadequate' product (fewer listings, slower process) that nonetheless satisfies the dimension that actually matters.

category_blind_spots.blind_spot: Post-agreement lifecycle management — no platform in the category provides tools for managing the ongoing reality of a shared-housing arrangement after the initial agreement is made. Date changes, payment tracking, cleaning verification, house-manual access, stay-by-stay reviews, and dispute resolution are universally absent or afterthoughts.
category_blind_spots.why_nobody_tries: Marketplaces are transaction platforms, not relationship-management platforms. Their business models, processes, and values are built around the moment of transaction, not the months that follow. Building lifecycle management would require becoming a different kind of company — not a marketplace but a relationship-management platform. Per Chapter 8, this requires different processes and different values, which is why Christensen argues that spin-out organizations are often necessary for this kind of disruptive innovation.
category_blind_spots.framework_insight: Chapter 9's performance oversupply model predicts this blind spot precisely. The market trajectory for shared housing is moving from 'can I find a place?' (discovery/search — oversupplied) to 'can I manage the ongoing arrangement effectively?' (lifecycle management — dramatically undersupplied). Every marketplace is competing furiously on the old basis of competition (listing volume, search features) while ignoring the emerging basis of competition (arrangement management). Christensen warns that 'most well-run companies migrate unconsciously to the northeast, setting themselves up to be caught by a change in the basis of competition and an attack from below by disruptive technology.' That attack from below is a platform that may have fewer listings but provides dramatically better lifecycle management.

category_blind_spots.blind_spot: Schedule-based housing as a distinct product category — no platform in the category recognizes that shared housing often operates on a schedule (specific nights per week, specific weeks per month) rather than continuous occupancy. Every platform assumes housing is a contiguous date range. Nobody provides scheduling primitives (nights-of-the-week selection, date swapping, schedule conflict detection) as first-class features.
category_blind_spots.why_nobody_tries: The mental model across the entire housing category — from Airbnb to Craigslist to Marketplace — is borrowed from traditional leasing: a tenant occupies a space continuously for a fixed period. The concept of time-shared housing on a recurring weekly schedule doesn't fit this mental model. No platform has recognized that a significant and growing segment of shared housing operates on schedules, not date ranges. This is a category-level assumption so deeply embedded that it's invisible.
category_blind_spots.framework_insight: Chapter 9 describes how disruptive technologies succeed by finding markets that 'value or accept' attributes that mainstream markets reject. Schedule-based housing is a market that traditional platforms would view as edge-case complexity — too niche, too complicated, too different from the standard booking model. But per Chapter 9, 'the weaknesses of disruptive technologies are their strengths': a platform built specifically for schedule-based housing would be 'worse' at traditional continuous-occupancy rentals but dramatically better for the underserved schedule-housing market. This is the classic disruptive beachhead — a market that incumbents dismiss as too small or too weird, but which, once served, creates the foundation for upmarket expansion.

category_blind_spots.blind_spot: The relationship as a first-class data object — no platform models the host-guest relationship itself as an entity that accumulates trust, history, norms, and value over time. Every platform models listings, bookings, and users as separate objects. The relationship between two specific people — their compatibility score, their history of successful stays, their accumulated trust — is not represented anywhere in any platform's data model or UX.
category_blind_spots.why_nobody_tries: Modeling relationships requires a fundamentally different data architecture and UX paradigm than modeling transactions. Marketplaces are built on a listing-centric model (the listing is the primary object; users interact with listings). A relationship-centric model (the host-guest pair is the primary object; arrangements are expressions of the relationship) requires rebuilding the conceptual foundation of the platform. No existing marketplace can retrofit this without rebuilding from the ground up.
category_blind_spots.framework_insight: Chapter 8's discussion of creating capabilities through spin-out organizations is directly relevant. Christensen argues that when an innovation requires 'a different cost structure in order to be profitable and competitive, or when the current size of the opportunity is insignificant relative to the growth needs of the mainstream organization,' a separate organization is required. A relationship-centric housing platform is precisely this kind of innovation: it requires different processes (relationship management vs. transaction facilitation), different values (trust depth vs. transaction volume), and a different cost structure (investment in trust infrastructure vs. investment in listing volume). No incumbent can build this within their existing organization.
